title: Impact of Demographic Changes on Inflation and the Macroeconomy
text: 6 Style Review Economists Jong-Won Yoon, Jinill Kim and Jungjin Lee offer an advanced analysis of global demographic shifts and their economic effects. Declining birth rates and longer-lived populations, particularly in developed countries, will have serious macroeconomic implications. People’s transitions from young borrowers to middle-aged savers to elderly spenders influence factors such as growth in per capita GDP, a country’s ability to balance its budget and inflationary pressures.   this scholarly research to policy makers, who seldom consider demographic changes when deliberating on economic strategy, inflation and interest rates. Perhaps they should.   population shifts and demographic changes will affect economies in the future Why policy makers should incorporate demographics into their monetary and fiscal policy planning Summary Evidence suggests that population trends, particularly in developed nations, could have far-reaching economic implications. In the short term, demographic shifts and the expected economic behaviors associated with them – that is, young people borrow, the middle-aged save and the elderly spend – affect...   report   or log in About the Authors Jong-Won Yoon is a former executive director at the International Monetary Fund, where Jungjin Lee is a senior research officer. Jinill Kim is a professor at Korea University.
